metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: The dynamic nature of homogeneous equilibria involving aqueous solutions or gases, and their representation by balanced chemical or thermochemical equations (including states) and by concentration-time graphs

closed_system_requirement.name: Closed System Requirement
closed_system_requirement.formula: No reactants or products enter or leave
closed_system_requirement.correct: Equilibrium can only be established in a CLOSED system where no reactants or products can enter or escape.

open system.error: Equilibrium cannot be established in an open system.
open system.fix: In open systems, products escape before reverse reaction can occur. Closed systems trap everything.
open system.action: Think: can an uncovered pot of boiling water reach equilibrium? No‚Äîsteam escapes.

isolated system.error: Isolated means no energy transfer either‚Äîthat's more restrictive than needed.
isolated system.fix: Closed system = no matter exchange. Energy can still flow in/out (e.g., heating).
isolated system.action: A sealed flask that you can heat is closed but not isolated.

any system.error: Not any system‚Äîequilibrium requires specific conditions.
any system.fix: Must be closed to matter. Open systems allow escape, preventing equilibrium.
any system.action: Compare: sealed bottle (equilibrium possible) vs open beaker (products escape).

persistent.gap: You don't understand why system boundaries matter for equilibrium.
persistent.action: List 3 examples each of open and closed systems. Which can reach equilibrium?

reversible_reaction_definition.name: Reversible Reaction
reversible_reaction_definition.correct: A reversible reaction can proceed in both directions‚Äîreactants form products AND products reform reactants simultaneously.

can be stopped and restarted.error: That's not what reversible means in chemistry.
can be stopped and restarted.fix: Reversible means the reaction runs BOTH ways at the same time, not that you can pause it.
can be stopped and restarted.action: Think of reversible as 'two-way traffic', not 'pause button'.

goes to completion both ways.error: Reversible reactions never go to completion‚Äîthey reach equilibrium.
goes to completion both ways.fix: Both forward and reverse occur, but neither finishes. Mixture of reactants AND products remains.
goes to completion both ways.action: At equilibrium, you have BOTH reactants and products present. Never 100% either way.

only occurs with a catalyst.fix: Many reactions are naturally reversible. Catalysts speed up both directions but don't create reversibility.
only occurs with a catalyst.action: N‚ÇÇO‚ÇÑ ‚áå 2NO‚ÇÇ is reversible without any catalyst.

persistent.gap: You're confusing chemical reversibility with everyday uses of 'reversible'.
persistent.action: Write the definition: both forward and reverse reactions occur simultaneously.

dynamic_equilibrium_definition.name: Dynamic Equilibrium Definition
dynamic_equilibrium_definition.formula: Rate forward = Rate reverse, concentrations constant
dynamic_equilibrium_definition.correct: At dynamic equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions occur at equal rates, so concentrations of reactants and products remain constant but NOT necessarily equal.

reactions have stopped.error: The reactions haven't stopped‚Äîthey're still occurring.
reactions have stopped.fix: DYNAMIC means movement. Both reactions continue, just at equal rates so no net change.
reactions have stopped.action: Imagine two escalators: people going up = people going down. Movement continues, but crowd size is constant.

concentrations are equal.error: Concentrations are CONSTANT, not necessarily equal.
concentrations are equal.fix: Constant means unchanging. Products and reactants can have very different concentrations at equilibrium.
concentrations are equal.action: K might be 1000‚Äîthat means far more products than reactants at equilibrium, but amounts stay fixed.

only forward reaction occurs.error: That would be irreversible, not equilibrium.
only forward reaction occurs.fix: Equilibrium requires BOTH forward AND reverse reactions occurring simultaneously.
only forward reaction occurs.action: If only forward occurred, products would keep increasing. They don't at equilibrium.

persistent.gap: You think equilibrium means 'stopped' or 'equal amounts'. It means 'balanced rates'.
persistent.action: Memorise: Dynamic = still moving. Equilibrium = balanced rates, constant (not equal) concentrations.

homogeneous_equilibrium.name: Homogeneous Equilibrium
homogeneous_equilibrium.correct: In a homogeneous equilibrium, all reactants and products are in the SAME phase (all gases or all aqueous).

all species have equal concentrations.error: Homogeneous refers to PHASE, not concentration.
all species have equal concentrations.fix: Homo = same. Homogeneous = same phase. Concentrations can be completely different.
all species have equal concentrations.action: In 2NO‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå N‚ÇÇO‚ÇÑ(g), both are gases (homogeneous) but concentrations differ.

the mixture looks uniform.error: Visual uniformity isn't the definition‚Äîphase is.
the mixture looks uniform.fix: Homogeneous equilibrium = all species in one phase (all gas or all solution).
the mixture looks uniform.action: A gas mixture is homogeneous. A solid in liquid is heterogeneous.

only one species is present.error: Equilibrium always has multiple species‚Äîreactants AND products.
only one species is present.fix: Homogeneous means same phase, not same substance. Multiple chemicals, one phase.
only one species is present.action: 2SO‚ÇÇ(g) + O‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2SO‚ÇÉ(g) has three species, all in gas phase = homogeneous.

persistent.gap: You're confusing 'homogeneous' with other chemistry terms.
persistent.action: Define: homogeneous = same phase. Practice identifying phases in equilibrium equations.

rate_vs_extent.name: Rate vs Extent
rate_vs_extent.correct: Rate describes HOW FAST a reaction proceeds. Extent describes HOW FAR (what proportion of reactants convert to products).

rate and extent are the same thing.error: They measure completely different aspects of a reaction.
rate and extent are the same thing.fix: A reaction can be fast but reach equilibrium with mostly reactants (low extent, high rate).
rate and extent are the same thing.action: Analogy: driving speed vs distance travelled. Different concepts.

higher rate means greater extent.error: No direct relationship‚Äîa fast reaction can have low extent.
higher rate means greater extent.fix: Catalysts increase RATE but don't change equilibrium position (extent).
higher rate means greater extent.action: Catalyst speeds up reaching equilibrium but doesn't change final concentrations.

extent determines the rate.error: Extent is about final position, rate is about speed. Different variables.
extent determines the rate.fix: Rate is controlled by activation energy, temperature, concentration. Extent depends on K.
extent determines the rate.action: Rate = kinetics (Chapter 5). Extent = thermodynamics (equilibrium constant K).

persistent.action: Make a comparison table: Rate (speed, kinetics) vs Extent (proportion, thermodynamics).

equilibrium_symbol.name: Equilibrium Symbol
equilibrium_symbol.correct: Reversible reactions at equilibrium are shown with the equilibrium symbol ‚áå (two half-arrows), not a single arrow ‚Üí or double arrow ‚Üî.

single arrow ‚Üí.error: Single arrow shows irreversible reaction, not equilibrium.
single arrow ‚Üí.fix: ‚Üí means one direction only. ‚áå shows both forward and reverse occurring.

double-headed arrow ‚Üî.error: ‚Üî is used in resonance structures, not equilibrium.
double-headed arrow ‚Üî.fix: Equilibrium uses ‚áå (two half-arrows). ‚Üî shows resonance electron movement.
double-headed arrow ‚Üî.action: ‚áå for chemical equilibrium, ‚Üî for resonance. Don't mix them.

equals sign =.error: Equals sign doesn't convey the dynamic nature of equilibrium.
equals sign =.fix: ‚áå emphasises that both directions occur. = just balances an equation.
equals sign =.action: The arrows in ‚áå remind us reactions go both ways simultaneously.

persistent.gap: You're using incorrect notation for equilibrium reactions.
persistent.action: Practice writing 10 equilibrium equations using ‚áå correctly.

state_symbols.name: State Symbols
state_symbols.correct: State symbols show physical state: (s) solid, (l) liquid, (g) gas, (aq) dissolved in water. Essential in equilibrium equations.

(w) for water.error: Water as solvent is shown by (aq) on the solute, not (w).
(w) for water.fix: (aq) = aqueous = dissolved in water. Water itself can be (l) or (g).
(w) for water.action: NaCl(aq) means salt dissolved in water. H‚ÇÇO(l) is liquid water.

(d) for dissolved.error: (d) is not a standard state symbol.
(d) for dissolved.fix: Dissolved substances use (aq) for aqueous. No (d) symbol exists.
(d) for dissolved.action: Memorise the four: (s), (l), (g), (aq). That's the complete set.

state symbols are optional.error: State symbols are essential in equilibrium equations.
state symbols are optional.fix: Phase matters for equilibrium expressions and homogeneous/heterogeneous classification.
state symbols are optional.action: Always include states. They tell you if equilibrium is homogeneous or heterogeneous.

persistent.gap: You don't recognise the importance of state symbols in equilibrium chemistry.
persistent.action: Write 5 equilibrium equations with all state symbols. Check each is correct.

concentration_time_equilibrium.name: Concentration-Time Graph at Equilibrium
concentration_time_equilibrium.formula: Lines become horizontal when equilibrium reached
concentration_time_equilibrium.correct: On a concentration-time graph, equilibrium is reached when concentration lines become HORIZONTAL (constant), though at different levels.

lines converge to zero.error: Concentrations don't go to zero‚Äîreactants remain.
lines converge to zero.fix: At equilibrium, BOTH reactants and products are present. Lines level off, not reach zero.
lines converge to zero.action: Equilibrium mixture always contains both. Neither side 'wins' completely.

all lines reach the same value.error: Lines become constant, but at DIFFERENT values.
all lines reach the same value.fix: Horizontal means constant. Different heights mean different concentrations at equilibrium.
all lines reach the same value.action: If K is large, product line is higher than reactant line. Still both horizontal.

lines continue to change.error: At equilibrium, concentrations are constant‚Äîlines must be horizontal.
lines continue to change.fix: Changing lines mean system hasn't reached equilibrium yet. Horizontal = equilibrium.
lines continue to change.action: The moment lines go flat, equilibrium has been established.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how to read equilibrium from concentration-time graphs.
persistent.action: Sketch 3 graphs showing approach to equilibrium. Mark where equilibrium starts.

graph_initial_changes.name: Initial Concentration Changes
graph_initial_changes.correct: Initially, reactant concentrations DECREASE while product concentrations INCREASE as the forward reaction dominates.

all concentrations increase.error: Reactants are consumed‚Äîtheir concentration must decrease.
all concentrations increase.fix: Reactants ‚Üí Products. Reactants decrease, products increase. Conservation of mass.
all concentrations increase.action: If A ‚Üí B, then [A] drops as [B] rises. Matter is conserved.

concentrations stay constant from start.error: That would mean equilibrium already exists‚Äîit takes time to establish.
concentrations stay constant from start.fix: System must react first before reaching equilibrium. Changes occur, then stabilise.
concentrations stay constant from start.action: Mix reactants ‚Üí reaction starts ‚Üí concentrations change ‚Üí eventually constant.

products decrease initially.error: Products are being formed, so they increase initially.
products decrease initially.fix: Forward reaction dominates initially (no products yet to react back). Products accumulate.
products decrease initially.action: At t=0, often no products exist. They can only increase from zero.

persistent.gap: You don't visualise what happens as equilibrium is established.
persistent.action: Draw the graph: reactants start high and curve down, products start low and curve up.

five_characteristics.name: Five Characteristics of Equilibrium
five_characteristics.formula: Closed, equal rates, mixture present, constant concentrations, constant macroscopic properties
five_characteristics.correct: The five characteristics are: closed system, equal forward/reverse rates, mixture of reactants and products, constant concentrations, constant macroscopic properties.

equal concentrations of reactants and pr.error: Concentrations are CONSTANT, not necessarily equal.
equal concentrations of reactants and pr.fix: Equal RATES, constant CONCENTRATIONS. Very different from equal concentrations.
equal concentrations of reactants and pr.action: Rates must be equal. Concentrations depend on K and can be very different.

no reactions occurring.error: Reactions continue‚Äîthat's what makes it DYNAMIC.
no reactions occurring.fix: Both reactions occur at equal rates. No NET change, but constant activity.
no reactions occurring.action: Dynamic equilibrium: motion without net change. Like a balanced seesaw with kids still moving.

only forward reaction occurs.error: Both directions must occur for equilibrium.
only forward reaction occurs.fix: Equilibrium requires forward AND reverse reactions at equal rates.
only forward reaction occurs.action: If only forward occurred, products would keep increasing. They don't at equilibrium.

persistent.gap: You don't know all five characteristics of equilibrium.
persistent.action: Memorise: Closed, Equal rates, Mixture present, Constant [conc], Constant properties.

macroscopic_properties.name: Constant Macroscopic Properties
macroscopic_properties.formula: Observable properties don't change at equilibrium
macroscopic_properties.correct: At equilibrium, macroscopic (observable) properties like colour, pressure, and density remain constant because concentrations are constant.

colour keeps changing.error: At equilibrium, colour is constant‚Äîconcentrations don't change.
colour keeps changing.fix: Colour depends on concentration. Constant concentration = constant colour.
colour keeps changing.action: NO‚ÇÇ/N‚ÇÇO‚ÇÑ equilibrium has a fixed brown colour once equilibrium is reached.

pressure keeps increasing.error: At equilibrium, all properties including pressure are constant.
pressure keeps increasing.fix: Constant amounts of all species = constant pressure (at fixed T and V).
pressure keeps increasing.action: If pressure kept changing, the system wouldn't be at equilibrium yet.

properties are zero.error: Properties are constant, not zero. Substances are still present.
properties are zero.fix: The reaction mixture has colour, pressure, density‚Äîall constant, all non-zero.
properties are zero.action: At equilibrium you have a mixture. It has properties. They just don't change.

persistent.gap: You don't understand that 'constant' means 'unchanging', not 'zero'.
persistent.action: List 5 observable properties and explain why each is constant at equilibrium.

equilibrium_basics.title: Understanding Chemical Equilibrium
equilibrium_basics.instructions: Complete the statements about the basic concepts of chemical equilibrium.

sentences.text: For a chemical system to reach equilibrium, it must be a {{d1}} system where no {{d2}} can enter or escape.

d1.tooltip: What type of system traps all matter inside?

d2.tooltip: What must be prevented from escaping for equilibrium?

sentences.text: A reversible reaction is one that can proceed in {{d3}} directions, meaning products can reform into {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: How many directions does a reversible reaction go?

d4.tooltip: What do products become in the reverse reaction?

sentences.text: In a homogeneous equilibrium, all reactants and products are in the {{d5}} phase, such as all {{d6}} or all aqueous.

d6.tooltip: Name a common phase for homogeneous gas equilibria.

dynamic_nature.title: The Dynamic Nature of Equilibrium
dynamic_nature.instructions: Complete the statements about what makes equilibrium 'dynamic'.

sentences.text: At dynamic equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions occur at {{d1}} rates, so the concentrations of reactants and products remain {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What must be true about the two reaction rates at equilibrium?

d2.tooltip: Do concentrations keep changing at equilibrium?

sentences.text: The term 'dynamic' means that reactions are still {{d3}}, while 'equilibrium' means there is no {{d4}} change in concentrations.

d4.tooltip: Changes occur both ways but cancel out. What type of change is zero?

sentences.text: The rate of a reaction describes {{d5}} a reaction proceeds, while the extent describes {{d6}} the reaction proceeds toward products.

d5.tooltip: Rate is about speed. What question does speed answer?

d6.tooltip: Extent is about proportion converted. What question does that answer?

equations_states.title: Equilibrium Equations and State Symbols
equations_states.instructions: Complete the statements about writing equilibrium equations.

sentences.text: Reversible reactions are represented using the equilibrium symbol {{d1}}, which shows that both forward and {{d2}} reactions occur.

d1.tooltip: Which symbol has two half-arrows pointing opposite ways?

d2.tooltip: The backward-pointing arrow represents which reaction?

sentences.text: State symbols in equations include (s) for solid, (l) for liquid, (g) for {{d3}}, and (aq) for substances dissolved in {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: Aqueous specifically means dissolved in what?

sentences.text: For the equilibrium 2NO‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå N‚ÇÇO‚ÇÑ(g), all species are in the {{d5}} phase, making this a {{d6}} equilibrium.

d5.tooltip: What does (g) indicate about the phase?

d6.tooltip: What do we call equilibria where all species share one phase?

concentration_graphs.title: Concentration-Time Graphs
concentration_graphs.instructions: Complete the statements about concentration-time graphs for equilibrium systems.

sentences.text: On a concentration-time graph, equilibrium is reached when the concentration lines become {{d1}}, indicating that concentrations are {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What shape indicates no change over time?

d2.tooltip: A horizontal line means the value is not changing.

sentences.text: Initially, as the forward reaction dominates, reactant concentrations {{d3}} while product concentrations {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Reactants are being used up. What happens to their amount?

d4.tooltip: Products are being formed. What happens to their amount?

sentences.text: At equilibrium, macroscopic properties such as {{d5}} remain constant because the {{d6}} of all species are constant.

d5.tooltip: Name observable properties that depend on concentration.

d6.tooltip: What quantity determines colour intensity and gas pressure?

equilibrium_basics.title: Applying Equilibrium Concepts
equilibrium_basics.instructions: Apply your understanding of equilibrium basics to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A sealed flask containing nitrogen dioxide reaches equilibrium because it is a {{d1}} system, but an open beaker would {{d2}} reach equilibrium as gases escape.

d1.tooltip: Sealed means nothing can enter or leave.

d2.tooltip: Can equilibrium be established if products escape?

sentences.text: The reaction N‚ÇÇ(g) + 3H‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2NH‚ÇÉ(g) is reversible, meaning ammonia can {{d3}} to reform nitrogen and {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What happens to products in the reverse reaction?

d4.tooltip: Look at the equation‚Äîwhat are the other reactants?

sentences.text: The equilibrium Fe¬≥‚Å∫(aq) + SCN‚Åª(aq) ‚áå FeSCN¬≤‚Å∫(aq) is homogeneous because all species are {{d5}}, meaning dissolved in {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: What does (aq) indicate about the state?

d6.tooltip: Aqueous specifically means dissolved in what substance?

dynamic_nature.title: Understanding Dynamic Processes
dynamic_nature.instructions: Apply your understanding of the dynamic nature of equilibrium.

sentences.text: Even at equilibrium, bonds are constantly being {{d1}} and {{d2}} as both reactions continue simultaneously.

d1.tooltip: Reactions involve bond changes. What happens in forward/reverse?

d2.tooltip: The opposite of breaking bonds is...

sentences.text: A catalyst increases the {{d3}} of reaching equilibrium but does not change the {{d4}} of the reaction.

d3.tooltip: Catalysts speed things up. What do we call speed in chemistry?

d4.tooltip: The final equilibrium position is not affected by catalysts.

sentences.text: At equilibrium, if the forward reaction produces 100 molecules of product per second, the reverse reaction must consume {{d5}} molecules per second, resulting in {{d6}} net change.

d5.tooltip: For no net change, rates must be...

d6.tooltip: Equal rates in opposite directions give what net result?

equations_states.title: Writing Correct Equilibrium Equations
equations_states.instructions: Apply your knowledge of equilibrium notation and state symbols.

sentences.text: The equation H‚ÇÇ(g) + I‚ÇÇ(g) ‚Üí 2HI(g) shows an irreversible reaction because it uses a {{d1}} arrow, whereas H‚ÇÇ(g) + I‚ÇÇ(g) {{d2}} 2HI(g) shows equilibrium.

d1.tooltip: How many arrow heads does an irreversible reaction show?

d2.tooltip: Which symbol shows both forward and reverse reactions?

sentences.text: In the equation CaCO‚ÇÉ(s) ‚áå CaO(s) + CO‚ÇÇ(g), this is a {{d3}} equilibrium because the species are in {{d4}} phases.

d3.tooltip: Solid and gas are different phases. What type of equilibrium?

d4.tooltip: Are (s) and (g) the same or different phases?

sentences.text: For the thermochemical equation N‚ÇÇ(g) + 3H‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2NH‚ÇÉ(g) ŒîH = ‚àí92 kJ mol‚Åª¬π, the negative ŒîH indicates the forward reaction is {{d5}}, releasing {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Negative ŒîH means energy is released, which is called...

d6.tooltip: What form of energy is released in exothermic reactions?

concentration_graphs.title: Interpreting Concentration-Time Graphs
concentration_graphs.instructions: Apply your understanding to interpret equilibrium graphs.

sentences.text: Before equilibrium is reached, the graph shows reactant lines {{d1}} downward and product lines {{d2}} upward.

d1.tooltip: Lines change gradually, not suddenly. What shape?

d2.tooltip: Products increase gradually as they form.

sentences.text: The point where all concentration lines become horizontal marks when {{d3}} has been established and the rates of forward and reverse reactions are {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What state is characterised by constant concentrations?

d4.tooltip: At equilibrium, what is true about the two rates?

sentences.text: At equilibrium, the product line may be {{d5}} than the reactant line if the equilibrium favours {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: More products means higher concentration on the graph.

d6.tooltip: If product concentration is higher, which side is favoured?

equilibrium_basics.title: Mastering Equilibrium Fundamentals
equilibrium_basics.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of equilibrium concepts by addressing common misconceptions.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that equilibrium requires an isolated system, but actually a {{d1}} system is sufficient‚Äîenergy transfer is {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Closed allows energy exchange but not matter exchange.

d2.tooltip: Can you heat a closed system to change equilibrium position?

sentences.text: Students often confuse 'reversible' with 'can be undone by cooling'. In chemistry, reversible means both {{d3}} and {{d4}} reactions occur simultaneously.

d3.tooltip: Which reaction converts reactants to products?

d4.tooltip: Which reaction converts products back to reactants?

sentences.text: The five characteristics of equilibrium include: closed system, equal {{d5}}, mixture of reactants and products present, constant concentrations, and constant {{d6}} properties.

d5.tooltip: What must be equal‚Äîthe amounts or the rates?

dynamic_nature.title: Advanced Dynamic Equilibrium Concepts
dynamic_nature.instructions: Demonstrate deep understanding of the dynamic nature of equilibrium.

sentences.text: Saying 'the reaction has stopped' at equilibrium is {{d1}} because 'dynamic' specifically means reactions are still {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Does dynamic equilibrium mean stopped or moving?

sentences.text: Concentrations at equilibrium are {{d3}} but not necessarily {{d4}}‚Äîa large K value means much more product than reactant.

d3.tooltip: Concentrations don't change at equilibrium. That means they are...

d4.tooltip: Could products and reactants have different concentrations at equilibrium?

sentences.text: A reaction can be fast but have low extent (mostly reactants at equilibrium), or slow but have high extent (mostly {{d5}} at equilibrium). Rate and extent are {{d6}} properties.

d5.tooltip: High extent means the reaction favours forming...

d6.tooltip: Does knowing the rate tell you the extent, or are they separate?

equations_states.title: Complex Equilibrium Notation
equations_states.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of equilibrium equations and notation.

sentences.text: The symbol ‚Üî is used for resonance structures, while {{d1}} is the correct symbol for chemical equilibrium, showing {{d2}} half-arrows.

d1.tooltip: Which symbol has two separate half-arrows?

d2.tooltip: How many arrows represent forward and reverse reactions?

sentences.text: For CO‚ÇÇ(g) + H‚ÇÇO(l) ‚áå H‚ÇÇCO‚ÇÉ(aq), this is {{d3}} because the species are in {{d4}} different phases (gas, liquid, and aqueous).
State symbols are essential because they determine whether an equilibrium is homogeneous or {{d5}}, which affects how we write the {{d6}} expression.

d6.tooltip: What type of expression uses K = [products]/[reactants]?

concentration_graphs.title: Advanced Graph Interpretation
concentration_graphs.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of concentration-time graph analysis.

sentences.text: A common error is thinking equilibrium means all lines converge to the {{d1}} value. In fact, lines become horizontal at {{d2}} concentration levels.

d1.tooltip: What misconception do students have about final concentrations?

d2.tooltip: At equilibrium, are all concentrations necessarily equal?

sentences.text: On the graph, the {{d3}} between the horizontal lines represents the relative concentrations at equilibrium, which is determined by the value of {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What do we call the vertical distance between lines?

sentences.text: If the system starts with only reactants, the graph shows reactant lines starting {{d5}} and curving down, while product lines start at {{d6}} and curve up until all lines become horizontal.

d5.tooltip: Initially, reactant concentration is at its maximum.

d6.tooltip: If we start with only reactants, how much product is there initially?

closed_system_requirement.title: Why Equilibrium Requires a Closed System
closed_system_requirement.content: Equilibrium can only be established in a closed system where no reactants or products can escape. In an open system, products would continuously leave, preventing the reverse reaction from occurring at a rate equal to the forward reaction.
keyPoints: Closed system: matter cannot enter or leave
Open systems cannot reach equilibrium‚Äîproducts escape
Isolated systems (no matter OR energy transfer) are more restrictive than needed

reversible_reaction_definition.title: Understanding Reversible Reactions
reversible_reaction_definition.content: A reversible reaction can proceed in both directions simultaneously
